text:
the form builder, if there is html in the labels of fields it displays the code.

Reason this matters - client thought they had to use the richtext feature to add formatting - they had a form that had no labels because all of it was in the rich text areas instead.

a vision impaired person using a screen reader would have probably and fairly thrown around a few curse words and went on to find a different company to handle their stuff.

I’ve been trying to be more conscientious of it lately. Had to work on a project where accessibility while it wasn’t a primary concern, I knew for fact a lot of people who needed to use assistive technologies or keyboard navigation would be using the site. Made me do a lot of digging into best practices. it’s a humbling experience to try to use those tools yourself and go through an old project, just to go… oh man… I completely failed some people.
Oh man using something like JAWS is an eye opener, thinking about giving the team a turn on it.
honestly I feel like a great policy to have would be to be like - all the devs and decision makers at the company have to use JAWS or mac OS’s built in thing for a minimum of 2 hours  every friday
